body:
### Describe the bug

As soon as Cython 3.1 has been released, a few hours ago, psycopg tests started failing. Example: [this workflow](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg/actions/runs/14916373880).

The failing tests are tests counting that there are no leaks.

Upon drilling down, the objects that leak seem to be PGresult. Code [here](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg/blob/e63f3aa9/psycopg_c/psycopg_c/pq/pgresult.pyx).

Curiously, but this might be an artifact of the way I am trying to drill down, what I see leaking are the _lists that contain the `PGresult`_ By changing the test the following way:

<details>
<summary>Patch to find the object leaking</summary>

```diff
diff --git a/tests/test_cursor_raw.py b/tests/test_cursor_raw.py
index b12128cf..000ec72b 100644
--- a/tests/test_cursor_raw.py
+++ b/tests/test_cursor_raw.py
@@ -92,17 +92,9 @@ def test_leak(conn_cls, dsn, faker, fmt, fmt_out, fetch, row_factory, gc):
                         cur.executemany(faker.insert_stmt, faker.records)
                     cur.execute(ph(cur, faker.select_stmt))
 
-                    if fetch == "one":
-                        while cur.fetchone() is not None:
-                            pass
-                    elif fetch == "many":
-                        while cur.fetchmany(3):
-                            pass
-                    elif fetch == "all":
-                        cur.fetchall()
-                    elif fetch == "iter":
-                        for rec in cur:
-                            pass
+    from gc import get_objects
+    from typing import Any
+    from psycopg_c.pq import PGresult  # type: ignore
 
     n = []
     gc.collect()
@@ -110,4 +102,21 @@ def test_leak(conn_cls, dsn, faker, fmt, fmt_out, fetch, row_factory, gc):
         work()
         gc.collect()
         n.append(gc.count())
+
+    leaked: list[list[Any]] = [[] for _ in range(3)]
+
+    for i in range(3):
+        work()
+        gc.collect()
+        for obj in get_objects():
+            if type(obj) is list and len(obj) == 1 and type(obj[0]) is PGresult:
+                leaked[i].append(obj)
+
+        n.append(gc.count())
+
+    got = set(map(id, leaked[0]))
+    more = [obj for obj in leaked[1] if id(obj) not in got]
+    for obj in more:
+        print(obj[0].command_status)
+    breakpoint()
     assert n[0] == n[1] == n[2], f"objects leaked: {n[1] - n[0]}, {n[2] - n[1]}"
```

</details>

then I could see that the objects leaked are 8 lists of precisely one item, being a PGresult instance, likely containing the query executed in the test. The print statement prints:

```
b'BEGIN'
b'DROP TABLE'
b'CREATE TABLE'
b'SAVEPOINT'
b'RELEASE'
b'SELECT 10'
b'ROLLBACK'
b'DEALLOCATE ALL'
```

Forcing Cython < 3.1 [in the build requirements](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg/blob/e63f3aa94d1a72d57ecffe5251240525621242c9/psycopg_c/pyproject.toml#L22) the leak disappears.

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

Clone psycopg 3 on current master, create a virtualenv, build and install the Cython extension, the testing dependencies:

```
$ git clone git@github.com:psycopg/psycopg.git
$ cd psycopg
$ git checkout e63f3aa9
$ python -m venv .venv
$ source .venv/bin/activate
(.venv) $ pip install ./psycopg[test] ./psycopg_c
```

Point the env var to a scratch database to run tests, run this sample test. All similar gc count-based tests fail:

```
(.venv) $ export PSYCOPG_TEST_DSN="dbname=psycopg3_test"
(.venv) $ PSYCOPG_IMPL=c pytest "tests/test_cursor_raw.py::test_leak[asyncio-tuple_row-iter-Format.BINARY-b]"
...
FAILED tests/test_cursor_raw.py::test_leak[asyncio-tuple_row-iter-Format.BINARY-b] - AssertionError: objects leaked: 8, 8
========================================== 1 failed in 0.18s ===========================================
```


### Expected behaviour

_No response_

### OS

Linux, Windows, macOS

### Python version

3.10 to 3.13. Not 3.8 to 3.9

### Cython version

3.1.0

### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body:
Note: I thought that the lists leaked were the one in the cursors. But that list is likely changed inplace [here](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg/blob/e63f3aa94d1a72d57ecffe5251240525621242c9/psycopg/psycopg/_cursor_base.py#L521) so there shouldn't be more than one instance per cursor. That code is pure Python, not Cython.

What I suspect is that the leak comes from the generator function where the list and the objects are created, which is in Cython too, [here](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg/blob/e63f3aa94d1a72d57ecffe5251240525621242c9/psycopg_c/psycopg_c/_psycopg/generators.pyx#L163).

Hacking more about these lists, adding the following to the test (and dropping the `leaked` lists):
```python
            # in the loops:
            if type(obj) is list and len(obj) == 1 and type(obj[0]) is PGresult:
                print(f"{sys.getrefcount(obj)=}, {len(get_referrers(obj))=}")

    # after the loops
    L = []
    L2 = [L]
    print(f"{sys.getrefcount(L)=}, {len(get_referrers(L))=}")

```
These print:

```
sys.getrefcount(obj)=4, len(get_referrers(obj))=1
sys.getrefcount(L)=3, len(get_referrers(L))=1
```

Which, I might be totally wrong here, but seem to suggest that the lists created in the generator have the refcount off by one.
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6878 is a duplicate of this issue but has additional information.

title: [BUG] Objects created with Cython 3.1 leak memory.
